Run differential abundance analysis

Source: R/differential-analysis.R
run_differential_analysis.Rd

Performs DESeq2-based differential abundance analysis on SGE screen data, using control oligos for size factor normalization.

Usage

run_differential_analysis(
  count_matrix,
  normalization_matrix,
  sample_metadata,
  condition_levels = c("Day4", "Day7", "Day10", "Day15"),
  shrinkage_type = "normal",
  alpha = 0.05,
  include_rate = TRUE,
  sample_prefix = "count_"
)

Arguments

count_matrix

Numeric matrix of variant counts with sequences as row names and samples as columns.

normalization_matrix

Matrix of neutral variants for size factor estimation (e.g., synonymous/intronic variants).

sample_metadata

Data frame with sample information. Must contain condition, duration, and supplier_name columns.

condition_levels

Character vector specifying condition factor levels in order (default: c("Day4", "Day7", "Day10", "Day15")).

shrinkage_type

Type of LFC shrinkage: "normal", "apeglm", or "ashr" (default: "normal").

alpha

Significance threshold for adjusted p-values (default: 0.05).

include_rate

Logical; whether to include continuous rate analysis (default: TRUE).

sample_prefix

Prefix used for sample column names in the count matrix (default: "count_"). Set to "" if column names match supplier_name directly.

Value

An SGEResults object containing:

results

DESeq2 results table as a tibble with SEQUENCE column (access via @results)

rlog

Regularized log-transformed DESeqDataSet object (access via @rlog)

contrast_summary

Combined summary across all contrasts including log2 fold changes, p-values, z-scores, and rate estimates (access via @contrast_summary)

metadata

Analysis parameters including condition_levels, shrinkage_type, alpha, and analysis_date (access via @metadata)

Details

This function implements the full SGE differential abundance pipeline:

  1. Extracts condition information from metadata for samples in matrix

  2. Estimates size factors from neutral variants (synonymous/intronic)

  3. Creates DESeqDataSet with proper experimental design

  4. Applies control-derived size factors to all variants

  5. Runs DESeq2 Wald tests for all condition contrasts

  6. Computes regularized log transformation for visualization

  7. Generates z-scores across samples for each variant

  8. Optionally runs continuous analysis for rate estimation

The control-based normalization strategy accounts for differences in library size while avoiding bias from variants under selection.

See also

estimate_size_factors(), create_normalization_matrix()

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
results <- run_differential_analysis(
  count_matrix = counts,
  normalization_matrix = norm_counts,
  sample_metadata = metadata
)

# Access components using @
deseq_results <- results@results
rlog_data <- results@rlog
summary_table <- results@contrast_summary
analysis_params <- results@metadata
} # }
